Tar, Nicotine Ratings Coming
By Don Oberdorfer Chicago Daily News Service
WASHINGTON-The fed- eral government is preparing to establish scientifically, and probably publish, the tar and nicotine "ratings" of popular brands of cigarets.
The potential result is a big switch in the brand preferences of millions of health-conscious smokers, and another king- sized crisis for the American tobacco industry.
Some officials believe such listings may set off a race among cigaret companies to produce brands low in tar and nicotine. On the basis of the government ratings, low-tar Brand A could skyrocket to commercial success while high-tar Brands B and C could plummet to obscurity. In the process, fortunes - could be made and lost.
Health Service and the Federal | tions be encouraged which will Trade Commission, had dis- result in the progressive re- duction of the tar and nicotine content of cigaret smoke." couraged public attention to the tar and nicotine contents of the smoke from various brands.
The agencies felt that too little was known about the medical significance of these elements to make comparisons meaningful.
Now the government ap- pears to be reversing itself -- under prodding from Congress and a panel of health experts.
Early last month an unan- nounced meeting of 14 experts -summoned here by the Pub- lic Health Service-concluded unanimously in a memorandum that "the preponderance of sci- entific evidence strongly sug- gests that the lower the tar and nicotine contents of cigaret smoke, the less harmful the effects."
The group recommended to UNTIL recently, the Public the surgeon general that "ac- Congress.
THE PUBLIC Health Serv- ice now has reportedly agreed to make a "comprehensive re- view" of the medical evidence on this subject, as suggested by Sen. Warren Magnuson (D-Wash.).
Moreover, the Federal Trade Commission began con- structing, in an old building on Pennsylvania Avenue, a cig- aret laboratory specifically de- signed to measure tar and nico- tine. The laboratory is sched- uled to begin operation within six weeks.
While no formal decision has been announced, FTC and the average smoker-in- sources said the laboratory re- sults of tests on individual brands will likely be made public-perhaps in reports to
PUBLICATION of similar data in the late 1950s by the Reader's Digest set off a "tar derby" of claims and promo- tion by various smokes. One filter-tip with a low-tar rating shot up almost overnight to best-seller status.
When new type filters or other changes gave hints to the public of greater smoking safety, sales have . boomed. Ironically, medical researchers say there is evidence that some recent filter-tip brands main- tain their taste by delivering as much tar and nicotine as nonfilter cigarets. ..
Government publication would doubtless have greater impact than tar-nicotine listings by any. private group .. U.S. "ratings" would be official,
creasingly sensitive to the health issue-might well rea- son: "If Uncle Sam puts out the information, it must mean something."
TO HALT the previous tar | though with the accompany- derby, the Federal Trade Com- ing disclaimer that "no health mission ruled two years ago claim is intended or implied by this listing." that cigaret companies could not advertise tar and nicotine contents of their brands. The FTC then considered such in- formation to be a "health claim," which might mislead consumers.
On March 25, however, the FTC rescinded this rule. One major cigaret firm, P. Loril- lard Co., almost immediately began marketing in New York City, a new filter-tip brand, True, with the tar and nico- tine 'content prominent in its advertising.
The company says the new brand . has "done very - well," and announced its extension to 10 additional cities coast to coast within weeks.
AMERICAN Tobacco Co. has also begun advertising the tar and nicotine contents of amount of tar and nicotine in its Carltons, a filter-tip brand, | their cigarets."
Such a disclaimer is in keeping with the regulations of the Cigaret Industry Adver- tising code. Lorillard withdrew from the voluntary code to be free to advertise True cigarets' tar and nicotine without the". disclaimer.
While controversial both in industry and medical circles, the proposed tar and nicotine , listings apparently ; will meet with public favor.
Two years ago the Public Health Service pollsters checked a random sample of Americans to discover their views on various aspects of smoking. At that time, 71 per cent believed that "cigaret companies should be required to put on the package the
